frontmatter.title: How to bring your own data to EDC: Using Sentinel Hub Python package

children.value: Getting started with Bring Your Own COG(BYOC)

children.label: Getting started with Bring Your Own COG(BYOC)

children.value: Sentinel Hub allows you to access your own data stored in your S3 bucket with the powerful Sentinel Hub API. Since data remains on your bucket, you keep full control over it. This functionality requires no replication of data and allows you to exercise the full power of the Sentinel Hub service including Custom algorithms.

has a very user-friendly “Bring your own COG” tab. If you are not going to be creating collections, adding/updating collection tiles, etc. daily, the Dashboard tool is your friend. For the rest, this tutorial is a simple walk-through on creating, updating, listing, and deleting your BYOC collections through Python using
In this demonstration Jupyter Notebook, based on the
Sentinel Hub Python package BYOC examples
Get a list of your collections
Manage BYOC tiles (cogs in the collection)
Creating a new tile (and ingesting it to collection)
Add multiple tiles to a single collection
Visualize the tiles in your collection

import sys
sys.path.append(“/home/jovyan”)
from credentials import *## Set up for prerequisites
Before accessing the data, we will start by importing the necessary Python libraries (already configured in your EDC workspace) and generate credentials automatically to access the services.

# EDC libraries
from edc import setup_environment_variables

# Utilities
import os
import boto3
import numpy as np
import datetime as dt
import pandas as pd
import geopandas as gpd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Sentinel Hub
from sentinelhub import (SHConfig, DataCollection, Geometry, BBox, CRS, 
                         SentinelHubRequest, filter_times, bbox_to_dimensions, MimeType, 
                         SentinelHubBYOC, ByocCollection, ByocTile, ByocCollectionAdditionalData,
                         DownloadFailedException)

# Configure plots for inline use in Jupyter Notebook
%matplotlib inline
Credentials for Sentinel Hub services are automatically injected as environement variables. It is therefore easy to populate Sentinel Hub’s credential manager with the values.

# Pass Sentinel Hub credentials to SHConfig
config = SHConfig()
config.sh_client_id = os.environ["SH_CLIENT_ID"]
config.sh_client_secret = os.environ["SH_CLIENT_SECRET"]
This example notebook will demonstrate how to ingest tiles from AWS S3 bucket taking
as an example. You will need aws credentials to access data on AWS S3 bucket. Please create a text file named
in your home directory with the following input:

The easiest way to create a collection is to use its dataclass:
s3 bucket (please see how to configure your bucket for Sentinel-Hub service

created_collection_name = created_collection['name']
created_collection_id = created_collection['id']
print('name:', created_collection_name)
print('id:', created_collection_id)
Get a list of your collections

children.label: Get a list of your collections

children.value: Now we have created a data collection named

Let’s have a look at the collection we just created.
In cases where you have a large amount of collections and you would only like to load collection info for a few collections, the following code would be a good option for you:

my_collection_using_next = next(collections_iterator)
my_collection_using_next
print('name:', my_collection_using_next['name'])
print('id:', my_collection_using_next['id'])

collection_to_be_updated = [x for x in my_collections if x['name']=='new collection'][0]
collection_to_be_updated['name'] = 'renamed new collection'

children.value: Manage BYOC tiles (cogs in the collection)

children.label: Manage BYOC tiles (cogs in the collection)

children.value: Your data needs to be organized into collections of tiles. Each tile needs to contain a set of bands and (optionally) an acquisition date and time. Tiles with the same bands can be grouped into collections. Think of the Sentinel-2 data source as a collection of Sentinel-2 tiles.

Tiles have to be on an s3 bucket and need to be in COG format. We will not go into details about the COGification process; users can have a look at the documentation or use the BYOC tool that will take care of creating a collection and ingesting the tiles for you.
Creating a new tile (and ingesting it to collection)

children.label: Creating a new tile (and ingesting it to collection)

children.value: When we create a new tile and add it to the collection, the ingestion process on the Sentinel-Hub side will happen, checking if the tile corresponds to the COG specifications as well as if it conforms to the collection. For more information refer to the
Bring Your Own COG API documentation
The simplest way to create a new tile is by using the
dataclass, which will complain if the required fields are missing. In the following cell we will show how to ingest
data listed on open registry data on AWS.
The most important field of the tile is its
on an s3 bucket. For example, if your band files are stored in
as the tile path. In this case, the band names will equal the file names. For example, the band B1 corresponds to the file

. If your file names have something other than just the band name, such as a prefix, this is fine as long as the prefix is the same for all files. In this case, the path needs to include this prefix and also the band placeholder:
. Adding the extension is optional. For example, this is what would happen if you would use the following path
- the file would be used, the band name would be B1
- the file would be used, the band name would be B2
- the file would not be used
- the file would not be used
as optional parameters, but setting the
is highly recommended since it makes the collection “temporal” and help you search for the data with Sentinel Hub services.
is optional as it is the bounding box of the tile and will be read from COG file.
is the geometry of where the data (within the bounding box) is and can be useful for optimized search as an optional parameter. For a good explanation of the
) will tell you if it has been
. In case of failure, additional information (with the cause of failure) will be available in the tile
Add multiple tiles to a single collection

children.label: Add multiple tiles to a single collection

children.value: A data collection can for sure contain multiple tiles. It is important to know that adding multiple tiles will work only if these tiles have the same bands. Let’s add more tiles from the
listed on the open data registry on AWS to the collection.
We first define a function to get a list of paths for each tile:
Next we obtain a list of paths for tiles available on
tiles_path = list_objects_path('sentinel-s2-l2a-mosaic-120', config.aws_access_key_id, config.aws_secret_access_key, y=1, m=1, d=1)
Then we can add tiles to the collection with a

for tile in tiles_path:
    byoc_tile = ByocTile(path=f'{tile}(BAND).tif', 
                         sensing_time=dt.datetime(int(tile.split('/')[0]), 
                                                  int(tile.split('/')[1]), 
                                                  int(tile.split('/')[2]), 
                                                  0, 
                                                  0, 
                                                  0)
                        )
    byoc.create_tile(created_collection, byoc_tile)
The tile ingesting process could take some time, please wait a few more minutes after the cell has done running before heading to the next step.
being executed, we can request the tile from the collection where it is ingested. To request one specific tile in the collection, you can do it by passing the collection id and the tile id to the
You can of course retrieve all tiles into a list.
In cases where you have a large collection with a lot of tiles and you would only like to load tile info for a few tiles, the following code using
would be a good option for you:
To convert it to ByocTile dataclass using the code below:
Let’s take a look at the keys of the first dictionary, which contains the info of the first tile, in the returned list.
To check if there’s any tile failed to be ingested, run the code below:

tiles_failed_to_be_ingested = [x['path'] for x in tiles if x['status']=='FAILED']
tiles_failed_to_be_ingested
Visualize the tiles in your collection

children.label: Visualize the tiles in your collection

children.value: dataclass, which will properly parse tile geometries, date-time strings, etc., one can create a
the geometries can be in different coordinate reference systems, so a transform to a common CRS might be needed.

tiles_for_visualized = []
for i in range(100):
    tiles_for_visualized.append(ByocTile.from_dict(next(tile_iterator)))

tiles_gdf = gpd.GeoDataFrame(tiles_for_visualized, geometry=[t.cover_geometry.transform(CRS.WGS84).geometry for t in tiles_for_visualized], crs='epsg:4326')
tiles_gdf.head()

children.value: In the above example, the ingested tiles are 100 tiles from the pull out from the
which contains 19869 tiles around the globe, hence the tiles are so sparse in the image above.
Updating and deleting a tile follow the same logic as updating/deleting a collection:
After updating we can see that the
Now the tile is gone forever.

tiles = list(byoc.iter_tiles(created_collection))
[x for x in tiles if x['id']==created_tile['id']]

Once we have a collection created and its tiles ingested, we can retrieve the data from said collection.
We will be using ProcessAPI for this.
Below we’re going to request a false color image of Caspian Sea.

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(15, 10))

ax.imshow(data)
ax.set_title(tile_time.date().isoformat(), fontsize=10)

plt.tight_layout()
